line_1: But for his appearance he payed full deare,
line_2: He couchde in his rest, his silver-poynt speere,

line_1: But for his appearance he payed full deare,
line_2: And ferslie ranne up in full career;

line_1: Poor Alma, like a lonely Deer,
line_2: O'er Hills and Dales does doubtful err:

line_1: And his are your dark-brown deer.
line_2: And my stepdame false your ear;

line_1: With deep-mouth'd notes rouse up the trembling deer.
line_2: The sprightly horn proclaims some danger near,

line_1: With deep-mouth'd notes rouse up the trembling deer.
line_2: And hounds, harmonious to the sportsman's ear,

line_1: When prowling Troops of Wolves some wand'ring Deer
line_2: In num'rous Concert hunt; she wing'd with Fear

line_1: Bear on the Haunch, and flea the living Deer.
line_2: From her fat Sides the reeking Morsels tear,

line_1: Six little, little Indian deer,
line_2: Would at a word fly every where,

line_1: Now sucking tallow of salubrious deer.
line_2: Now swallowing bitter draughts of Prussian beer;

line_1: And when Thou frequent bring'st the smitten Deer;
line_2: (For seldom, Archers say, Thy Arrows err)

line_1: Thy toils be now to chase the bounding deer,
line_2: Or view the coursers stretch in wild career;

line_1: Are couched the mountain deer;
line_2: No haunts of men are near.

line_1: 'This Hand shall well revenge my slaughter'd Deer:
line_2: She said: And furious grasp'd the dreadful Spear,

line_1: And startling from their haunts the timid deer,
line_2: Which Waller's soothing lyre were wont to hear,

line_1: Poor England! thou art a devoted deer,
line_2: Beset with ev'ry ill but that of fear.

line_1: Pursu'd with equal Speed the flying Deer,
line_2: And of the Spoils there no Divisions were.

line_1: To L—, and worry those small deer
line_2: When He might do more precious mischief here?

line_1: The din alarm'd the frighten'd deer,
line_2: Who in a corner slunk for fear;

line_1: By twinkling star-light drive the flying deer;
line_2: Who over Alps of snow, and desarts drear,

line_1: Dried up the cows and lamed the deer,
line_2: Who prowled the country far and near,

line_1: While like a herd of tim'rous deer
line_2: Thy army shakes and pants with fear,

line_1: Loose the fierce Tyger from the Deer,
line_2: For native Rage and native Fear

line_1: At the rough Boar; or chace the flying Deer:
line_2: Go, with Thy Cynthia, hurl the pointed Spear
